title: SPRI bead mix

source.description:
In 50 mL volumetric flasks, prepare a separate 50 mL stock solution for each of the following components with the specified weights of solids.
Some gentle heating may be necessary. Ensure the solution comes back to room temperature before completing the volume to the mark on the flask. Store in 50 mL conical tubes.
Optional: filter the stocks with the syringes and filters to remove undissolved solids. It is strongly recommended to filter the solutions used for making RNA mix for sterilization.

source.description: Making 50 mL of 10% (v/v) Tween 20 stock
Place a labeled 50 mL conical tube on the balance and tare it.

With a new disposable Pasteur pipette, aspirate
to
of

Slowly dispense the
into the 50 mL conical tube to reach
.

Remove the tube from the balance and add
of
with a 25 mL serological pipette.

Cap the tube and mix on a rotary mixer for
to dissolve the viscous liquid.
Making 25 mL of 50% (w/v) PEG 8000 stock

source.body: This recipe can be scaled up with larger cylinders to make mixing easier, for example making 50 mL of solution in a 100 mL cylinder.

source.description: Place the 25 mL graduated cylinder on the balance and tare it.

Weigh
of
powder directly into the cylinder. It is recommended to use a fresh pair of gloves to reduce static charges that make the powder fly off the spatula.

Add no more than
of
with a serological pipette on top of the PEG powder in the cylinder. The water level will reach over the 25 mL mark as the cylinder already contains about 20 mL of dry powder. Be sure not to fill the cylinder completely, as some air is required to make mixing possible. If the cylinder is too small, use a 50 mL one.
Seal the cylinder with a double layer of Parafilm.
Shake vigorously to suspend the powder in the water until there are no more lumps of dry solid sticking to the cylinder wall. It will be very viscous and clumpy.

Let the suspension stand at room temperature for at least
to allow the solids to dissolve and the air bubbles to rise.

Remove the Parafilm and complete the volume with nuclease-free water to the
mark.
Seal the cylinder again and mix well by inverting. The solution is very viscous and homogenizing it can take a while.

Transfer the solution to a 50 mL conical tube for storage. There will be some loss inside the cylinder but you need only
for one batch of bead mix.

Nucleic acid elution and storage buffers
These solutions are used for preparing the beads before adding them to the mix. They are also useful for DNA and RNA elution and storage. It is possible to make concentrates of these solutions for convenience. Keep them refrigerated.

source.name: Sera-Mag SpeedBead Carboxylate-Modified Magnetic Particles (Hydrophobic), 15 mL

source.description:
Quickly transfer
to a 1.5 mL microcentrifuge tube (the beads settle quickly).

Place the tube on a magnet stand until the supernatant is clear, about
.
Remove and discard the supernatant.

Add
of previously prepared "DNA buffer" or "RNA buffer", depending on the kind of bead binding mix you are preparing, to the bead pellet and close the tube.

Remove the tube from the magnet and resuspend the beads by vortexing for at least
. Spin down the liquid with a microcentrifuge.
Put the tube back on the magnet until the beads clear.
Remove and discard the supernatant.
, for a total of 3 washes with the appropriate buffer, leaving the supernatant in the tube after the last wash.

In a new 50 mL conical tube, combine the
,
and
. For DNA, also add the
and
. For RNA, add only the
instead. Cap and mix well.
Remove the buffer supernatant from the bead tube still on the magnet.

Add
of incomplete binding buffer (prepared at step 6.10) to the bead tube on the magnet.

Remove the bead tube from the magnet and resuspend by vortexing for
. Briefly spin down the liquid without pelleting the beads.

Add the washed beads to the incomplete binding buffer. Cap and vortex for
.

With a 25 mL serological pipette, add
of
. Dispense slowly and allow the viscous liquid to slide down the inside walls of the pipette to ensure an accurate volume is added.

Add the
.
Cap the tube and mix by inversion gently but thoroughly, until the color appears homogeneous.

The bead binding mix is ready to be used or validated. Store at
.

source.description:
Prepare at least
in a glass bottle from available concentrated stock.

It is recommended to validate the bead mixes before use to ensure their effectiveness. They can be compared to AMPure XP or RNAClean XP, or to a previous batch of homemade mix. Validation can be done with DNA or RNA that is representative of a typical usage scenario, a DNA ladder (note that NEB ladders may contain modifications that make their SPRI behaviour unrepresentative of normal DNA), fragmented DNA across a range of sizes, or an RNA standard.

cases.title: Example with DNA smear
cases.description: {"blocks":[{"key":"agmr7","text":"Fragment λ phage genomic dsDNA (e.g. Thermo Scientific #SD0011) with the NEBNext® dsDNA Fragmentase® kit (NEB #M0348S) for 20 minutes, according to the manufacturer's instructions, and purify the reaction product with 2 volumes of previously validated beads, then elute in TE+Tween. This produces a flat smear (50 to 2000 bp) that is easy to see on an agarose gel or an Agilent Bioanalyzer DNA 1000 chip. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"sbi2","text":"\n","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"216rh","text":"Re-purify the DNA with the reference DNA bead mix and the new DNA bead mix side-by-side using 2 volumes of beads. After elution, test the DNA on agarose gel or Bioanalyzer to compare the repurified samples with each other and with the original fragmented stock. If the yields and size distributions from the two bead mixes are equivalent, the new mix is ready for use. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c7sp9","text":"\n","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9qr9o","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5me8h","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"offset":0,"length":1,"key":0}],"data":{}},{"key":"bt91p","text":"Validation done with λ phage genomic dsDNA as specified above and  loaded on an Agilent Bioanalyzer DNA 1000 chip. Fragmented stock was  purified with AMPure XP (3 measurement replicates) and the test sample with homemade bead mix (3 purification replicates) both at 2 volumes of bead mix. Different amounts of DNA were loaded (approximately 25 ng stock, 40 ng repurified DNA) but the size distributions are very similar. This batch of mix was successfully validated.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"imageblock","data":{"guid":"60541F1C188811EB95740A58A9FEAC2A","height":"357","is_video":false,"mime":null,"original_name":null,"placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/public/3e64caff6b2fec9e3be63f4a30ee882eced1feccf036de9d959cec730f1f8a5b/cpjcbg3f7.png","source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/public/3e64caff6b2fec9e3be63f4a30ee882eced1feccf036de9d959cec730f1f8a5b/cpjcbg3f7.png","width":"550"}}}}

cases.title: Example with RNA standard
cases.description: {"blocks":[{"key":"9b08v","text":"To test the RNA bead mix, dilute FirstChoice Human Brain Reference RNA (Life Tech #AM6050) 100-fold to 10 ng/μL in Citrate+Tween. Purify the dilution using the RNA bead mix and elute in Citrate+Tween. Load the original input and the purified output on an Agilent Bioanalyzer RNA 6000 Pico chip.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dbvf8","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b4dob","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"offset":0,"length":1,"key":0}],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","data":{"guid":"6D6265DF188811EB95740A58A9FEAC2A","height":336,"id":79139,"is_video":false,"legend":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"c9i7p","text":"The original diluted input (red) was loaded with samples purified using different ratios of RNA bead mix: two volumes (blue), one volume (green) and half volume (cyan). The samples were denatured before loading.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}},"mime":"image/png","original_name":"image.png","placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/public/3e64caff6b2fec9e3be63f4a30ee882eced1feccf036de9d959cec730f1f8a5b/cpjdbg3f7.png","source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/public/3e64caff6b2fec9e3be63f4a30ee882eced1feccf036de9d959cec730f1f8a5b/cpjdbg3f7.png","type":1,"width":550}}}}

description:
This protocol describes the preparation of stocks and buffers for inexpensive, convenient, and scalable DNA and RNA purification from aqueous solutions by solid-phase reversible immobilization (SPRI) on carboxylated paramagnetic beads. It also describes how to validate the effectiveness of the mixes before use.
The bead mixes described in this protocol are drop-in substitutes for AMPure XP and RNAClean XP beads (Beckman Coulter), but at about 1/100 of the cost (~$0.55/mL vs. $15–$70/mL at current Canadian prices).
